text.tspan: You have to understand the hero, your audience.
that gets them out of bed
what they spend time and money on
what do they admire and seek
This is a turning point, capturing the
audience’s intrigue and interest. The gap
have to be clear: this is a totally changed
world that we envision here, building
Using non traditionnal methods creates a
dynamism that keeps the audience engaged.
For the audience, the end of the presentation is the
beginning of a journey in a special world. Now commiting
to your idea, will they strive to change the world.
As a mentor, to guide the audience though its
journey, are you going to bring…
to propel them on their journey
that they will use to succeed
To the audience, what are going to be the benefits…
how the whole world is changed
And, are the outcomes benificial to…
Now is time to convert ideas into actionnable material.
Are each heros of your audience going to act as…
working hard to make things happen
providing access to resources they own or control
speading your idea and gaining new supporters
creating new ideas, strengthening your own
A lecture or speech given in front of an audience
A demonstration or display of a product or idea
Will they be reluctant to change because of their…
of the idea or its implications
and the shift in power caused by your idea
delivers an experience, not just information (emotion contrast)
contrast between what is familiar/comforting and what is stimulating
**GOAL of the presentation: by meeting with the mentor (presenter),
crossing the threshold and entering the special world**
emotion contrast => outcome: Connect with people
The Big Idea: 1. a complete sentence 2. conveiying what’s at stake 3. in a unique point of view
1. beginning: the state of things and of the hero “Ordinary World” / comfort zone
2. CLEAR turning point: “surprise effect”, envisioning a complete different outcome than what was thought
===> capture the audience’s intrigue and interest: “Call to Adventure”
3. building desire for a change of things and the hero => this is the Big Idea
4. showing how it can be fullfilled
BUT envisionning roadblocks => reluctance to change
(for the call to adventure, what is the current state)
lifestyle? and how do they live
knowledge? and what you bring new in it
motivation and desire? that gets them out of bed
values? on which they are ready to spend money and time
example? they follow and that influence their life
conception of respect? and how you can make them feel respected
As a mentor, to accompagny they journey, are you going to bring them some
guidance? like new knowledge and insights
tools? they will use to suceed in the adventure
In order to connect, do you share with them some
goals? you are aiming for the future
sacrifice? beliefs, ideals, or even time and money
take some risk? and confront emotional issues
How are they are going to deal with their
comfort zone? and their tolerance for change
misunderstanding? of the proposed change and implications
obstacles? that stop them to commiting, mental or practical
politics? and the shift in power caused by your idea
their sphere of influence? such as friends, peers, students
basic needs? such as water and shelter
recognition? promotion or access to exclusivity
what solutions are possible? need to answer the “Refusal of the Call”
STAR moment? connecting with the audience at the highest degree
6. call to action!!! what to do for: the DOERS, the SUPPLIERS, the INFLUENCERS, the INNOVATORS
7. the “new bliss”: what could be the state of things
8. what are the rewards for 1. the hero? 2. it sphere? 3. the mankind?
this is NOT the end!!! everything still is to do => now entering the special world
It all starts with it; it leads every
message of the presentation. This is…
in a unique point of view.
